Name: Leave it to Beaver: Rocket to the Moon
Description:
Space themed roll and move game based on the TV show "Leave it to Beaver"
Object of Game is to be the first player to reach the moon. Players flip a rocket-shaped cone onto a board to find out how many spaces to move their marker. The path to the moon is full of perils and traps which players must avoid.
Families: TV Shows: Leave it To Beaver

Name: Battle Animals Playing Card Game
Description:
From the manufacturer:

Battle Animals is a game of strategy, much like chess, where each card has its own strengths and weaknesses.  Learning how and when to use each card is the key to the game.

Name: CrossOver
Description: Similar to Blokus, players lay down colored tiles on a field. Tiles must connect "via a straight line drawn from any of the corners of their last tile, but the line must be in continuous contact with tiles of the same color to be valid."

Name: Sport Teasers
Description:
A collection of several different sports-themed games (e.g. baseball, basketball, football, tennis, golf, soccer, bowling) with simple wooden boards and pegs for score keeping and a pair of dice for each game.

Packaging is a round metal tin.

Most games require players to take simple actions that correspond to the different possibilities of dice roll from 2 to 12.

Name: Marblix
Description: The players tries to land their MARBLIX as close to the center of the play area as possible while also attempting to knock away an opponent's well-placed MARBLIX, just like curling.

Name: Batailles de L'Ancien Regime 1740-1763
Description:
Battailles de l'Ancien Regime 1740-1763 (BAR) is, despite its French title, a set of miniatures rules in English designed to simulate European land warfare in the mid-18th century.  The players supply the figures at any desired scale.  The hallmark of these rules is the highly detailed and historically meticulous system for portraying the various types of military organization during this period.  Units consist of variable numbers of figures and constitute infantry battalions, cavalry regiment and artillery batteries.

Despite its deliberately "Old School" design (i.e., large-sized units, figure removal, historically accurate rules on movement and changes of facing), the rules use modern mechanics and so do not require the writing of orders.  Existing miniature armies need not be re-based to use this rules set.  The rules book is self-published but has been produced to a high standard of quality.

*  72 pages including the color cover
    * Quick Ref. Charts for large/small games, miniatures and/or tables.
    * If you know the 18th Century, you can play right away with just the Quick Reference Charts.
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Monster Quest
Description:
From the Website...

"Monster Quest is a fun and exciting game, with nine years of play testing by fantasy gamers. If you like dungeons and a dragon or two than you will love a game of Monster Quest. The game doesn't take days or weeks to prepare it's ready to go in minutes right out of the box. Monster Quest is a mythological board game that leads a player through a magical land of action and adventure. Monster Quest has 226 spaces on the board and 450 cards.  There are Spell cards, Wisdom cards, Map cards, Monster cards, and even Property cards that can be bought during the game.  The cards are one of the ways that a player develops their character.  Also, the cards give the player the ability to move about the land of Monster Quest rather than relying solely on the chance of the dice.

There are 12 different parts to the game-board, a main trail that connects all of the different parts of the game-board together, a Town Adventure, a Dungeon, six Inner trails, and three Outer trails.

Each player has a pegboard to keep track of their Hit Points (HP), Armor Class (AC), Platinum Pieces (PP), Gold Pieces (GP), Silver Pieces (SP), Jewels, and the Experience (Exp.) that a player will gain during the game.

Monster Quest uses two sets of dice, two six-sided and two eight-sided.  The dice are used to Battle Monsters, win treasure, and move about the land of Monster Quest.

A game of Monster Quest can last anywhere from three to five hours depending on the level of difficulty you wish to play.  Monster Quest can be played by two to four players.  There are six jewels in the game protected by monsters; a player must collect all six jewels to win the game.  Monster Quest is a whole world on one board where strategy is key.

Beyond the City Gate treasure awaits in dark Caves, along Wooded Trails through the Emerald Forest on Shipyard Docks across the Black Sea to thirst in the Desert wandering the Foothills to the Mountains of Doom on your way to the King?s Castle to save the Princess.  BEWARE of the Dungeon on your quest young squire and if you have what it takes the jewels can be yours."

Name: Titeuf Le Jeu
Description:
Titeuf is a well known animated series comic character in France. In this game you help him and his gang passing a day in  school. You will have to master hilarious challenges.

Beside 220 cards and a dice there will be also a mini ball launcher and a basket to throw the ball in.

Name: The Productivity Management Game
Description:
Produced in 1974 by the "Educational Products Inc. Division of Westinghouse Learning Corporation". The contribution of "Mark Coker, Productivity Management Consultant" to the development of the game is acknowledged.

"The Productivity Management Game presents real life simulations of situations and activities leading to the improvement of productivity in a variety of businesses and industries. Improved productivity contributes to profitability and lowered consumer costs.

Game Objective: to undertake three productivity improvement projects for an organization and to complete the projects on or ahead of schedule, with anticipated or greater savings for the organization." [preamble to the rules]

Name: Dandy Candy Game
Description: Extrapolated from a Games Gone By article. Game is based a lot on CANDYLAND. Board is 13 X 20 and features places like Lollypop Land, Candy Cane Lane and Gumdrop Islands. The game included 4 wooden pawns, a candycane spinner. Object of the game was to make your way through the maze and finish at the candy store. First one there won the game.

Name: Tru-Action Electric Track Meet
Description: From the same company who made the famous Tru-Action Football game (The one with all of the men with plastic legs that when you turned on the power "ran" all over the place. This electric action game features 4 Sprinter racing figures. There are two different kinds of tracks on the field (board). One features the regular running events like the 100 yard dash, the 220, the 440 and the mile run. A separate track was used to run the low hurdles. The low hurdle track had bumps on it so that at least in theory the runners actually jumped over those low hurdles as they came down to the finish line.

Name: Zing It!
Description: Card game involving bidding and trick taking.  Card set includes four colors with numbers 1 through 15 plus a variety of special cards which invoke unusual rules.

Name: Holidays in Switzerland
Description: A simple roll-and-move game wherein players travel through Switzerland, trying to be the first to complete the route.  There are a few additional random elements, including cash (which players must produce at various points along the path) as well as a few talent contests (such as singing the first verse of a song, and moving a number of spaces depending upon how well one has sung) or answering some trivia questions about the current town.

Name: Video Varmints
Description: Players attempt to blow as many varmints into their opponent's goal as possible in this air powered game.

Name: Yippee Rolling Game
Description: Players take turns rolling small wooden balls down a sloped gameboard.  The gameboard features holes of different point values.  Players try to get their balls into the various holes to score points.

Name: Big League Game of Baseball
Description: Dice Baseball game using 3 D6 dice to determine the outcome of each pitch.  The game board included 10 wooden pegs for recording base runners, outs, balls and strikes.

Name: The Peculiar Game of My Wife and I
Description:
From the National Museum of Play Online Collection:
"One of the most popular children's games of the late 19th century was called "Peter Coddles and his trip to New York," or some variation of that title. The games true origins have been lost but it is thought that it was first developed by McLoughlin Brothers in New York, though nearly every competitor produced one or more versions. Some, such as this version, bore completely different titles but followed the same method for play. It is a very simple word game best played with a large group of children, so it lent itself to social gatherings, parties, or holiday functions. The game consists of cards, usually small printed strips, with word groups printed, usually nouns. A leader reads the 'story' supplied with the game and when he/she encounters a blank, the first player to the left supplies the words from the card drawn. The play advances around the table, with nonsensical humor increasing with each blank in the story. Versions range from simple to deluxe--with quite complicated printed stories supplied. The game relates to other word games of its time such as Anagrams and to contemporary word games such as Boggle and Mad Libs."

Name: Mythes et Légendes: Le jeu des Univers Fantasy et SF
Description:
Players in Mythes et Légendes  tell a story about a hero with a pre-determind happy ending. Each turn, players add a card to the storyline and add to the story.

If the story makes no sense, other players can vote against the story and the storyteller loses his turn.

When all conditions for the happy ending are met, the first player playing a card with a black marker can tell the ending and win the game.

All cards in the game use artwork used in novels published by Pocket.

There are a few special ¨magic¨ cards that can change the course of the story.

Name: Drums of War Along the Mohawk
Description:
These rules are designed to simulate land combat in North America during the French and Indian Wars, 1744-1766.  The rules are geared to lower intensity warfare from skirmish level to brigade-sized actions.  They may also be extended to the frontier warfare of the previous century as well as the era of the American War of Independence.

The style of the rules are "Old School" in the sense of relatively high figure density with considerable attention to actual unit organization.  Extensive notes and information are provided in the rules book on units such as Scottish Highlanders, American Rangers, Canadian Militia, and Indian Allies among others.  The rules also include such "chrome" elements as "How to Portray an Eighteenth Century Leader" (Chapter 4) as well as rules for colonial sieges.

The rules set concludes with the design for a campaign game set during the struggle for Lake George in New York state.  An area map is also provided.

Name: To the Banners:  Rules for Pike & Shot 1500-1700
Description:
These rules are designed for fast play during an era of European land warfare across two centuries.  They strive for simplicity while providing a feeling for the nature of battle during this time.

The rules are tuned to enable simulation of smaller scale actions rather than the large-scale battles that are more commonly the focus of miniatures rules but were more infrequent than the types of actions (raids, ambushes, assaults and patrols) these rules are suitable for.

Given this scale of focus, the rules are designed for play with 25mm figures but may be easily re-scaled for 15mm.  Rather than offer army lists as such, these rules instead provide lists of characteristics of various unit types (e.g., gendarmes, landsknechts, various nationalities of shot and pike) by period:  Tudor Wars, Italian Wars, Thirty Years War, English Civil Wars, and Louis XIV.  Along with these lists, there is a system for generating armies based on unit cost.  A representative scenario is provided for each of the five periods of the lists.
Families: History: War of the League of Cambrai

Name: Ridiculous Vanity
Description:
Ridiculous Vanity is a miniatures rules set that simulates European politics and land warfare during the age of Louis XIV.  It is really two games in one.  The first is a campaign game where the players are national leaders engaging in politics and moving forces across a map of Europe divided into areas with differing economic and strategic value.  The second is a set of miniatures rules for simulating battle from 1660 to 1715.  The rules may be used exclusively of the campaign system and vice versa.

The rules do not require re-basing from other rules systems.  The units are standardized with infantry battalions consisting of 12 castings, two cavalry squadrons are 4 castings each.  The number of castings per stand varies with foot and cavalry types.  Armies are organized into commands and orders are issued to commands and groups.

The book includes several campaign scenarios set for different periods beginning in 1660, 1680, 1690 and 1701.  There is also one battle scenario for the Battle of Utrecht, 1676.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Killer Katanas II
Description:
Killer Katanas II is the revised version of a set of miniatures rules designed to simulate warfare in Japan during the 16th and 17th centuries.  The designer has also been a consultant on several recent board games on samurai warfare and renaissance era Japan.

The rules support two different scales of battle.  In the small scale a base of figures represent 120-150 foot or 60-75 horse.  The larger scale enables simulation of the biggest battle of the era.  Each base represents 240-300 infantry or 120-150 cavalry.

The rules cover all the unit types of the era including Ronin and Warrior Monks.  Further, the author includes nearly two dozen classical Japanese army deployment patterns.  Besides the rules, the booklet contains extensive lists of leaders and their ratings as well as army lists, ten historical battle scenarios and a scenario generator.

Name: Criminal Mouse
Description:
Criminal Mouse is an Italian game (written in part by prisoners) about being in prison in Italy. Players are incarcerated rats living their daily lives. Although an educational game, it is not recommended for children under 14 years.

Winner of "Archimedes 2004" special mention for its high social value.

Name: Building Boom
Description: Players construct a vertical track using plastic pieces then marbles down the track.

Name: Lucky Gnomes
Description:
[From the box description]

Collecting mushrooms is fun! The one who finds the most mushrooms is a real lucky gnome.

There are red, blue, and yellow mushrooms hidden under 33 panels of tufts of grass. The players hop from tuft to tuft with three colored goblins and uncover the panels again and again. The player who can remember the the most colors finds most mushrooms and wins.

Name: Johnny Ringo Game
Description: Roll and move game where players round up rustlers.  Based on the CBS TV show "Johnny Ringo" staring Don Durant.

Name: Stoney Burke
Description: Roll and move rodeo game based on the ABC TV show "Stoney Burke" staring Jack Lord.

Name: The Game of Emigration
Description: This game's theme is the Mormon emigration from Nauvoo to the Valley of the Great Salt Lake. The game includes a “pioneer odometer” spinner, game pieces (covered wagons and pioneers on foot), and 150 quiz cards.  Game play takes the pioneers on the Mormon trek through Iowa, Winter Quarters, and past obstacles like buffalo stampedes, Indians, skunks, cliffs etc. The Game of Emigration was locally produced in Utah with limited production and distribution.

Name: Know Your Gospel
Description: Know Your Gospel is a LDS (Mormon) trivia game for families or small church groups with questions focusing on scripture, church doctrine, and church history.

Name: The Disciple
Description: This is a religious themed game where players answer trivia/knowledge questions about Jesus Christ and his teachings in order to advance on the board and earn the status of a "Disciple."  There are various levels of questions so that adults and children can play together

Name: Nephi's Knowledge
Description: This is a religious (LDS/Mormon) trivia game using material from the Book of Mormon which was marketed for family or small church groups.

Name: Mormon Sports Trivia
Description: Mormon Sports Trivia is very similar to the game Trivial Pursuit, except all questions deal with LDS history,  sports, and Mormon athletes. This game was published as a follow up to the success of LDS(Mormon)game "Jots and Tittles" and even uses a Jots and Tittles gameboard. There are six trivia categories: 1) Play on the Field, 2) Action on the Court, 3) Competition in the Arena, 4) Figures and Personalities, 5) Great Moments and Achievements, and 6) Miscellaneous.

Name: Paleotopia
Description:
Free, downloadable, educational board and card game designed for students, Grades 5 through 7, that teaches the fundamentals of paleontology -- digging in the field and researching about what you find.

From the website:

"You're a paleontologist, searching the world for pre-historic remnants and evidence of past life. As you move through the landscape you'll need to dig for discoveries (in the dig spaces) and research for information on what you dig up in your adventures (research spaces.) Your goal is to set out from the University in search of evidence of past life and return after you match 5 Dig Cards with their correct Research Card. Be the first to make it back to the University with your matches and you become the Paleontology Professor and game winner."

Game files (available as one pdf file and broken up into several pdf files) freely available on website.

Webpage also includes the game's design process and game variants.

Home Page: http://www.soozzone.com/paleotopia.htm

Name: Gene Autry's Dude Ranch game
Description: A simple roll and move game where players collect markers as the circle the board.  Interestly, the flip side of the gameboard features a stock car racing game.

Name: Bockige Esel
Description:
A hardly known Tom Schoeps game. Each player tries controls a donkey and tries to get his oranges into town first (because the earlier you arrive the better the prices are...).
On your turn you can move forward which costs one food. Distance is 1-6 depending on the space you are starting from. Second possibility is to move one space backwards which gets you one food. Each player also gets a set of tactical cards that allow to manipulate the distance a bit. 
Games reminds a bit of Hare and Tortoise, but has got enough elements to be an 'independent' game.

Name: The Game of Terry and the Pirates
Description: The Game of Terry and the Pirates was produced by the Whitman Co. in 1937. Special dice let Terry, Pat, Connie, Dale, Old Pops and the Bandits to try and move around the board in an attempt to collect the treasures. Playing pieces included 4 wooden markers for the characters and 4 wooden scoring markers. The playing board had different things that could happen to any of the players in the game. Players start in Shanghai and attempt to collect the treasure and leave the board.

Name: Treasure Trek
Description: Treasure Trek is a family trivia game aimed at members of the LDS (Mormon)faith.  As players roll and move around board, they encounter Book of Mormon events, doctrines, and sites.  Questions contained in each trek are from that particular area of the scriptures.

Name: Tennis Shoes Among the Nephites: The Game
Description: A roll of the die takes players into Book of Mormon lands.  Players answer gospel questions to collect Gold Plates.  Special questions for players ages eight and under.  Theme based on the popular series of books by Chris Heimerdinger.

Name: Railways of Europe
Description:
Rails of Europe is an expansion for Railways of the World. Glenn Drover, one of the two designers of the original game, has designed a European setting for the expansion, which uses the original game's pieces, tiles, money, trains, shares and rules, along with a new map and card deck. There are some rules changed and added for the expansion to reflect the new setting of the expansion.

Due to the complicated corporate history of Eagle Games, this expansion was unusual - it was originally an official, yet unlicensed expansion of Railroad Tycoon. It was official, since the designer of the original game also designed this expansion and it was to be published by a company that is a descendant (of sorts) of Eagle Games.  The expansion is unlicensed because it never bore the Railroad Tycoon name, which was licensed from Sid Meier's computer game. Its status as an expansion of Railways of the World is much more official, although it existed before the base game of Railways of the World was published.

Name: Garroway's Game of Possession
Description: Geography based boardgame where the players buy and sell US States.

Name: Ant Farm Game
Description: Board game simulating an ant farm as player use tweezers to move the small lifelike plastic ants throughout the underground colony.

Name: Let's face it
Description: A face building game where players use plastic pieces to create funny looking faces for the game characters.

Name: Pinhead
Description: Labeled "the hide and seek game" it's nothing more than a roll and move game.

Name: Casino Bingo
Description:
Fast paced game in which players bet chips and then spin a wheel trying to fill up slots on a card.

Game includes a heavy-duty plastic bidding tray with an enclosed spinner. 4 cards for players to keep track of numbers called. And bidding chips.

Ages 8 and up.

Name: Identity Crisis?
Description:
With elements of games like Celebrity, Time's Up! and Taboo, Identity Crisis is a team-based game where you compete to guess famous identities based on the clues given by your team mates. In the first round you give verbal clues, in the second round you give one-word clues (to the same celebrities used in round one). You also have "Crisis" cards, which indicate that players from either team can guess on this turn. The game includes a timer to limit the clue givers to one minute.

From The Box

Players compete to identify the famous and the infamous, the real and the fictional, during two rounds of play.

In the Identity round, use as many words as you like to describe the identity. In the Crisis round, use only one word! Can you describe someone in one word? It's a challenge...but that's all part of the Crisis!

Engage in a little 'identity theft' and steal points from the other team.

The board game was the later inspiration for the syndicated game show Celebrity Name Game hosted by Craig Ferguson.

Name: Santa Anna Rules: Warfare in Mexico – 1820-1870: Volume 1 – Tactical System
Description:
These rules simulate land warfare in Mexico, 1820-1870.  The rules permit simulation of all the many conflict during this time including the Mexican-American War and the Maximillian War.

Units are infantry battalions, cavalry regiments and artillery batteries.  The rules give a playable game while providing a remarkable feel for the warfare of this time and place.  Unit morale is critical.  Casualties are indicated by figure loss but there are also losses to straggling.

The rules also provide two scenarios for the Mexican-American War (Buena Vista and Churubusco) as well as for the battle of Puebla in 1862 and for San Jacinto during the War for Texas Independence.
Families: History: Latin American Wars of Independence

Name: General-at-Sea: Wargames Rules and Scenarios for Fleet Actions, 1640-1721
Description:
General-at-Sea is a set of rules and scenarios for fleet actions, 1630-1721.  They were mainly designed for 1/2400 and 1/3000 models although 1/1200 may also be used.  The rules use a multi-ship system that permits large actions to be fought to conclusion in good time.

The rules also include scenarios for the Anglo-Dutch wars as well as for the later periods of the War of the League of Augsburg and the War of the Spanish Succession.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Captain-General: Wargames Rules and Army Guides for Land Battles, 1660-1721
Description:
These rules simulate land warfare in Europe during the period 1660-1721.  One centimeter represents about 20 yards.  Units represent infantry battalions, cavalry regiments and artillery batteries.

Units are made up of stands with variable number of figures and units are also made up of variable numbers of stands depending on unit type.  Foot units are differentiated by tactical doctrine:  platoon firing, shock, rank firing, skirmish, dragoons, etc.  There are similar differences among the horse units.

The rules come complete with a very large set of army lists of various nations from the different period covered by the rules.
Families: History: War of the Spanish Succession

Name: Might and Reason
Description:
Might and Reason is designed to provide a fast-play set of rules that will simulate large-scale land warfare during the period of the War of the Austrian Succession and the Seven Years War.  They allow players to game the larger battles of the period to a conclusion in just a few hours time.

Units are made up of multiple stands of miniature figures that represent units of brigade size.  The rules are consistent with any basing system. There are also rules for pre-battle scouting and post-battle pursuit.

The rules set also includes two complete campaign systems:  an all-European grand campaign as well as a campaign tool kit for creating one-year campaigns within a given theater.

Home Page: http://www.sammustafa.com/mr.html
Families: History: War of the Austrian Succession

Name: Undercover: The Game of Secret Agents
Description: Spy themed game has players trying to find an escape route while avoiding enemy agents and hazards.  Players use special "Infra-scope" goggles to help find and use underground supporters as they try to escape.

Name: EL
Description: A pencil and paper game in which the first player to form an EL(six different numbers in a line with no more than one right angle turn) wins.  A quick playing game that still contains a good deal of strategy.

Name: A Game About The United Nations
Description: Players compete to fill seats on the U.N. security council.  Combines political theme with monopoly-like roll and move mechanics.

Name: Blasto
Description:
"The Game of Space Tag"  This is a nuclear/space themed version of Battleship.

From the rules .....

Blasto is a battle between two space fleets.  Regular Blasto is played by two players.  Three may play, however, if two game boxes are used.  See note under variations at the end.  The object of the game is for each player to locate and destroy his opponents' fleet.  The player who accomplishes this first is the winner.  Occasionally there will be a tie game.

Name: Stagecoach
Description: Simple wild-west themed spin and move game.  Game includes 12x12 cardboard game board, spinner & 5 wooden discs for pawns.

Name: Doc Holliday Wild West Game
Description: Simple roll and move game that has the theme of Doc Holliday going after the "bandits."

Name: Portfolio
Description:
A set collection game in which players' melds earn them money.  Cash can be used to draw more cards and to neutralize or steal opponents' melds.  Players may extend or protect their own melds.  Most money at the end wins.

The game is played with two or three ordinary decks of playing cards.

Name: Erstes Rechnen
Description:
This game can be played in various formations. One game is played like Memory with players turning over tiles to find matching numbers. Another game has players rolling dice and selecting tiles that match the total and then filling up a player mat.

Translation of description from speldatabase.be
Six large boards each contain 10 drawings. Each time the sequence of numbers from 1 to 10 visually presented. Each card has its own theme. All 60 illustrations are also at much separate tickets.

The rulebook suggests many different ways to use this material.

As a warm-up, each player gets a playmat. The legkaartjes be dealt on the table and each player is trying to quickly collect ten cards.

Later, a lottery game played which also drawing upon the memory. The legkaartjes now lie face down in the middle. On his turn, each player now looking for tickets that fit with the player's mat.

The box also contains two regular dice. That you can use the right cards to collect. After looking dice each player a card with the same figure.

Each player who wins all ten cards can collect.

The illustrations are today but what about old fashioned charm because of their simple charm. Young children look really illustrations bearing the requisite number image is. The many game modes make this game more than once can be used.

Apparently a different game from the same-titled Erstes Rechnen.

Name: Laita
Description: Laita is a game of tactics played on an irregular 4x5 diamond board.  It can be played by two, three or four individual players, or by four players in a partnership game.

Name: Four Square
Description:
Four Square (4²) is a tactical game that can expand from one board to many, and where the playing area can wax and wane and twist and turn.

It is available as 2 or 4 boards, with the unique option of add-on boards.   A total of 6 different boards are available.

Name: Chiaroscuro
Description:
Chiaroscuro is an advanced version of Fleur Designs' game "t'other" for 2, 3 or 4 players. Most of Fleur's games have simple rules - the interest is in the tactics - and although Chiaroscuro's rules are, like the others, short they are more complex and need the ultimate in concentration.

Your task is simple if you've placed your pieces well.  But can you keep track of your opponents?

Name: t'other
Description: t'other is a simple strategy game and was designed with a modern Wars of the Roses in mind. It's not possible to explain without giving the full rules but those not from either side of the Pennines will be relieved to know that even southerners and foreigners will be capable of playing the game and no phrase book is required!

Name: Schildi Strandkröte
Description:
[From publisher:] The visitors of the Beach Stadium all look agog with expectation at Twiddle Turtle: Will she be the best again at rolling, skittling, and playing boule in the 2222 Olympics? A potentially record-breaking game collection with game board printed on both sides.

Can be combined with: Schildi SchildkrÃ¶te

Name: Buggy Bingo
Description:
Spin, count and match! Children build counting skills for numbers 1-10 while learning about insects. Spin the numbered bug wheel.  The first player to cover three leaves with bugs in a row, wins!

Includes four laminated game cards with fun bug facts on the back, spinner and 36 markers. For 2-4 players.

Name: Discovery Battling T-Rex Game
Description:
Lunge, dodge and attack in a head-to-head battle between two mighty foes.

Tail controllers enable full control over the action
Built-in sensors keep score
Powerful roaring sound effects
Articulated dinosaur action
Realistic prehistoric landscape
Step back in time as dueling dinos roar, snarl and battle each other. Just grab the tail controller and challenge a friend to see which dinosaur rules.

Name: Dora Bingo
Description:
"The classic game of Bingo has a new twist with Dora and all of her friends.  Kids and adults will enjoy this Bingo Adventure!"

Dora Bingo is classic bingo, but without the numbers and letters.  Instead, colors and pictures of the Dora characters identify each spot, and a spinner is used to call out the spaces.  Red Swiper, blue Boots, orange Dora, etc.  Simple enough for four-year-olds.  Game includes four cards and a spinner, and can be stretched to five players if one calls out the spots while the other four play.

Note that this game includes small plastic disks to cover the spaces, which could pose a choking hazard to very small children -- clearly marked on the package.

Ages 4 and up

Name: Sesame Street Preschool Games for Growing-Shapes
Description:
From the box: "Each GAMES FOR GROWING game set contains a variety of game materials that are used in various combinations depending on the particular game played.
Games for Growing-Shapes has instructions for 8 possible games.
Game 1 Shape Pair Game, object is to collect the most pairs of shape cards before opponents.
Game 2 Remember-A-Shape Game, object is to collect most pairs of shapes by remembering where they are. 
Game 3 Spin-A-Shape Game. object is to get rid of your cards by matching the spinner.
Game 4 Fish for Shapes Game, object is to collect the most pairs of shape cards by going "fishing."
Game 5 Shape Rummy, object is to get rid of your cards in your hand before any other players by grouping shapes into sets. 
Game 6 The Funny Train Game, object is to complete a train of three of the same shapes or five different shapes.
Game 7 Sherlocks's Great Shape Mystery Game, object is to collect the most cards by matching mystery cards with cards in your hand.
Game 8 Mumford's Hiding Shapes Game, object is to Collect the most cards that make pictures by finding the hidden shapes in the picture.

Name: World Bank
Description:
World Bank: The Game casts players as governments of developing countries. The goal of the game is to acquire resources of various kinds, dealing with debt, foreign aid, multinational cartels and natural events in the process.

While the game involves rolling and moving around a circular board, there are a number of subtleties; players may trade amongst themselves, establish cartels for uncommon resources, and even engage in wars.

Name: Krikos
Description: Krikos uses (circular) Byzantine Chess board, colours it as modern chess, uses modern chess pieces and moves and an additional set of new rules.

Name: Hex Agon
Description: Hex Agon is an abstract strategy game that can be played for different ways, including versions that allow for solitaire play and for up to six players to play.  Mechanics involve racing of pieces, capturing of pieces, and placement strategy.

Name: Crazy Horse
Description: Simple roll and move game. Game came with a game board, 4 Blue Horse pegs, 4 Green Horse pegs, 4 Red Horse Pegs and 4 Yellow Horse pegs and a die for movement

Name: Show Business: The New Game from Emile Littler
Description:
The Littlers - Emile, Prince & their sister Blanche were at one time the most powerful figures in the theatrical world of the West End & Provincial theater, with almost a total monopoly in producing musicals & pantomime in the UK.

This game was designed by Emile & was intended to give an interesting insight into the numerous hazards to the pursuit of stardom.

Players, starting from the Village Choir, would throw the dice & proceed along the track towards the School of Dramatic Art obeying the various directions on the way.

The correct number required must be thrown to finish on Stardom & the first player to reach here wins the game.

Amongst others Emile Littler was responsible for putting the young Radio & Variety star, Julie Andrews, into his pantomimes as the Princess in 'Aladdin' & this game is a delightfully produced & highly collectible period piece.

Name: Renaissance Warfare
Description:
Renaissance Warfare was third in the SAGA series of rulebooks for period warfare.  It is a set of miniatures rules simulating land warfare in Europe and Asia from 1494 to 1690.  It may be used with any scale of figures.  There are extensive rules for organization but players may use figures based in the standard DBx format with little problem.

The rules contain rich detail on warfare in this period of many unit types while still providing a playable game that will see a result in a few hours.  There are 49 army lists that themselves provide a rich source of information and cover the important armies of Asia as well as those of Europe.  There are also lists for relatively minor powers such as two lists for Ireland and one for the Knights of St. John.

Name: Cossack Wars
Description:
Cossack Wars is a set of miniatures rules designed to simulate small-scale warfare between cossacks of the 17th and 18th century.  It is a skirmish-type wargame with individual figures representing single cossacks.  They are given various personalized characteristics.

The rules are simple and perhaps somewhat reduced to produce quick play.  The rule book also contains 13 prepared scenarios of various sizes of which the largest would require 180 figures (360 figures to also represent dismounted cossacks) and the smallest 30 (60).

Name: Husaria: Wargames Rules and Army Lists for Eastern Europe from 1558 to 1699
Description:
Husaria is a set of miniatures rules designed to simulate land warfare in Eastern Europe during the period 1558-1699.  Given the subject matter, there are many rule elements designed to convey the unique context of war in the East.

Each figure represents 60-100 men.  The units are portrayed by stands of figures and represent what in the West during this period would have been brigade-sized groupings.  There is a clever interactive system for players to build armies from detailed army lists for all the varied armies of this period:  Polish Commonwealth, Cossacks, Tatars, Ottomans, Muscovites, Lithuanian, Swedes, etc.

There is also a very large list of leaders with micro bios as well as a listing of important battles from the period.
Families: History: Classical Age of the Ottoman Empire

Name: Cities! Busy Places, Friendly Faces
Description: Cities! Busy Places, Friendly Faces is a game associated with the Kindermusik music education program, aimed at preschoolers.  The game is actually a collection of several games, each with its own deck of cards and instructions.  Most all of the games involve matching pictures on the cards with pictures on the board.  In one game, "Busy City" for instance, one person selects a card, and then pantomimes the image or activity on the card for other players to guess.

Name: Sustainability
Description:
Free downloadable (Australian) trivia boardgame about environmentalism. Answer 10 points worth of questions about people, the environment and economics, then reach the sustainable Earth space to win.

The board and the question cards are provided. You will need to provide 2 six-sided dice and optionally, an egg timer.

Name: Ancient Wargaming
Description:
From the editor's introduction:

In this "Ancient Wargaming" book, Phil Barker (a founder member of the Wargames Research Group) sets out to introduce the fascinations of the period to the novitiate ancient wargamer. He describes not only the troop types, weapons and tactics of the period, but also shows how to begin amassing armies of wargame figures which are balanced in their composition, and how to use these same armies to win ancient battles on the tabletop using the Wargames Research Group Ancient Rules.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Black Hole Explorer
Description:
Black Hole Explorer is an interesting children's game about building a rocket to travel to and study a black hole. The game is designed to be light-hearted, educational and fun.

The game is played in three steps:

First construct your ship using what funds you have available -- $10 million to $60 million. Your ship must have probes, radiation shielding, gravitational strength and power to drive your spaceship.

And, don't forget to name your spaceship!

Next, travel to the black hole and enter into a low enough orbit with it to launch your probes.

There are spaces around the black hole to draw Event cards that may help or hinder your mission.

Finally, escape the black hole's gravity (which is harder than getting there), return to Earth and study the data from your probes. Did you gather enough information to win the Nobel Prize? The first player back gets to roll for the chance first. But is he or she fails, then the next finisher gets the chance.

The game has competitive and collaborative playing options, and also information for playing the game with large groups.

Name: Big Damn Range Wars
Description: Basic Cowboys and Indians game from Crunchy Frog, part of the 'Big Damn' series of games.  Includes cardboard cut-out figures, but can also be played with plastic Cowboy & Indian figures.  Simple combat mechanic results in a quick, bloody battle; Basic game doesn't take terrain into effect so movement is based on an included 'ruler' which determines how far you can move.  5 pages of rules(including the optional rules), plus 5 scenarios.

Name: Ancient Battles for Wargamers
Description:
Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

A wargamer's guide to classic battles and fighting men of ancient times is based upon a popular series which first appeared in the magazine Military Modeling. Charles Grant here describes in great detail the classic battles of ancient times, the men who fought them, their equipment and mode of fighting.

Name: Wargame Tactics
Description:
Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

"Wargame Tactics" will be welcomed by enthusiasts old and new, by Generals good, bad and downright indifferent. For it demonstrates that victory on the wargames table can be achieved (and usually is) by the player who adheres to the tactics of the period in question and to the basic principles of the art of war. It therefore follows that the player who studies the military background of his particular period will not only derive more enjoyment from his hobby, he will also win more battles.

Name: Solo-Wargaming
Description:
Adapted from the inside dust jacket:

Solo-Wargaming caters for both the player who cannot find opponents, and the player who wants an additional fix between sessions with friends!

It describes innumerable methods of maneuvering two wargame armies under such conditions of secrecy and surprise that the result of the battle is in the balance until the last cannon is fired. It opens many doors to ingenious and practical methods of doing battle with model soldiers, raising the pastime in some sense almost to the level of chess.

Microbadge:

Name: Warmaster Armies
Description:
Expansion for Warmaster

Warmaster Armies by Rick Priestley was published in 2006 as an expansion and clarification for Warmaster, Games Workshop's 10-15mm fantasy miniatures game.  This expansion gives 14 new, complete, and official army lists.  These lists include updates on the races and nations included in the original Warmaster book, as well as making some lists that had appeared in various GW magazines "official."  In making the step to being "official" it also shows they have been play-tested and are, for the most part, balanced.    A brand new list, Araby, with magic carpets and genies, is also included.

This list is superior in its presentation of the individual army rules.  Both army composition rules and rules for play, are boiled down to a single page for each race and nation.  Each race's spells are also presented.

Armies included are:
Empire (human)
Tomb Kings (undead)
Chaos
Orc
High Elf
Dwarf
Skaven
Lizardman
Bretonnia (human)
Kislev (human)
Dark Elf
Vampire Count (undead)
Daemon
Araby

This book was made available for free as a downloadable pdf.  It looks like GW originally planned to print it, based on the b/w interiors rather than color, but went the online route instead.

Name: Sesame Street PreSchool Games for Growing: Going Places
Description: This is an educational game that uses two different game boards for 2 different learning levels to teach children the concept of "going places," including methods of transportation and locations to travel to.

Name: Sea Turtle Survival
Description:
Free print-and-play game to teach children about the problems facing sea turtle survival.

Each player starts with 10 turtle tokens, and the game can end when any player increases his population to 50 tokens, or when after a set number of turns, the player who has the largest population. If a player runs out of turtle tokens, he is out of the game.

There are 4 variable conditions that help or hinder population growth. Each time a six is rolled on the dice, spin the spinner to see if these conditions (human interaction, climate, predators, and food availability) flip-flop from high to low or from low to high:

As players move around the board, cards may be drawn to collect or lose turtle tokens, change conditions, and gain tokens by answering trivia questions.

As players complete one life cycle and cross the start space, their turtle population increases based on the current population.

If players arrive at the same space at the same time, the turtles tussle producing more (baby) turtles for both players.

All components, except pawns and turtle tokens are available to download at the website: http://edweb.sdsu.edu/courses/edtec670/Cardboard/board/s/seaturtle/seaturtle.html

Name: Kannst du die Monate?
Description: An educational game for children to help them learn the months of the year, and what event occur in each month.

Name: Conni feiert Geburtstag
Description:
Conni is having a birthday and all of her friends are invited.  Come to the party with them!

Her mother has baked a delicious cake.  Everyone wants a piece of it, but only those that have a place at the table with Conni can get a piece of cake.

The clock is set and it begins!  This game requires observation and quick reactions.

Contents:

    A real clock with bell
    5 wooden dice
    1 sticker
    30 Birthday guests
    6 plates
    1 Birthday table
    1 Little-hippo chip
    Instructions



Conni hat Geburtstag und alle ihre Freunde sind eingeladen. Feiert mit !

Ihre Mama hate einen leckeren Kuchen gebacken. Alle wollen etwas davon haben, doch nur, wer einen Platz am Tisch mit Conni ergattert, bekommt ein Stück vom Kuchen ab.

Die Zeit-Uhr wird gestellt und los geht`s ! Bei diesem Spiel sind genaues Schauen und eine schnelle Reaktion gefragt !

Inhalt: 

    1 echte Zeituhr mit Kuchendruck
    5 Holzwürfel
    1 Aufkleberbogen
    30 Geburtstagsgäste
    6 Krümel-Teller
    1 Geburtstagstisch
    1 Seepferdchen-Chip
    1 Anleitung

Name: Molimba
Description: A two player trick taking game in which the objective is to go out first with a two- or one-suited hand of nine cards. Players start with nine randomly dealt cards and two face down "shed" cards between them. Standard no-trump trick-taking rules apply (with aces high) and the loser of the trick exchanges two of his cards (without revealing them) for the two face down cards.

Name: Springer
Description:
From Games of Art, Springer is a game based on the artwork of Ferdinand Springer.

The object of the game is to connect all four sides and claim at least a minimum number of points by filling in spaces on the board.  Play is restricted not allowing you to fill in a space that shares a side with a space of your color already filled in.

Name: The Oxford History of Board Games
Description:
"The Oxford History of Board Games investigates the principles of board games throughout the ages and across the world, exploring the fascinating similarities and differences that give each its unique appeal, and drawing out the significance of game-playing as a central part of human experience - as vital to a culture as its music, dance, and tales."

"Beautifully illustrated, and with diagrams to show the finer points of the games, this is a fascinating and accessible guide to a richly rewarding subject"

Name: Plunder
Description: A three-player trick taking game in which each player gains control of an exposed dummy after winning a trick.  The trump suit for the hand changes depending on which player controls the dummy.

Name: Overlord: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles
Description:
OVERLORD: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles is an expansion module for The Killing Ground: Campaign for Normandy, July-August 1944 that covers the period from June 6, to July 5, 1944. This 30 game-turn module links directly to The Killing Ground with an additional map, playing pieces and rules. It may also be played as a single map, stand alone game. In either case, the original The Killing Ground game is required to use this module.

OVERLORD: D-Day and the Beachhead Battles is divided into three stages, each with a different sequence of play. 
1. D-Day: June 6, 1944
2. OVERLORD: The Build-up
3. The Killing Ground

D-Day: June 6th, 1944 sequence of play is used only on game-turn one. OVERLORD: The Build-up sequence of play starts on turn 2 and ends the Game-turn in which both Allied nationalities have completed their depots. The Killing Ground: Campaign for Normandy, July-August 1944 sequence of play starts the turn after the depots are completed. The rules from the original Killing Ground game are used throughout the Build-up except were noted. The rules for D-Day and OVERLORD are in addition to and supersede the standard Killing Ground rules until the end of the Build-up. 
  
The OVERLORD expansion module includes the following:

     24 page OVERLORD Rules Booklet
     D-Day Turn 1 Sequence of Play Booklet
     2nd edition Killing Ground Rules Booklet
     North map section ; 22" x 34" (2 sided)
     280 back-printed, die cut counters (1/2 inch)
     Game Turn Record Track
     Sequence of Play Card (2 sided)
     Breakdown Battalion recombination guide
     German Set-up card
     D-Day and Build-up Charts and Tables card
     Combat Manual Pamphlet
     Guide to Replacement Counters
     Allied Tracks and Tables Single Map Supplement Card
     CRT Card


Most units are regiments; armor and other assets are battalions. At one day per turn and 2.5 km a hex.

(from publisher's page and BGG users)

Name: Spyhunting
Description:
Spyhunting is a 2-player strategy game whereby one player acts as the hunter and one player is hunted a.k.a. the spy.

This game can be played with standard equipment (checkerboard) from the average gamer collection in addition to some non-standard dice.

The spy’s objective is to travel from one corner to the opposite corner and back without being “shot.”  The hunter’s objective is to “shoot” the spy before he or she accomplishes his or her objective.

This game was a Top 11 finalist in the 2002 Board Game Design Competition called "Simultaneous Action Design" awarded by About.Com.

Name: Odds And Evens
Description:
Odds and Evens is a 2-player strategy game that can be played with components found in the average gamer collection.

The object of the game is to be the first player to move all of your pieces to the opponent's home row.

Players take turns rolling two six-sided dice and moving pawns on a standard checkerboard.  A unique rule to the game completely eliminates any advantage earned of one player rolling better dice combinations.

Name: Luck O' The Irish
Description:
From the Rules:  THE LUCK O' THE IRISH is the game for Kings of Ireland, Leprechauns, Fairies, and the Little Folk.  It is played by means of pieces being moved around the playing board, Ireland, according to throw of the dice.

The players set off from Dublin taking any road they wish and on their journey around Ireland must collect a Pot of Gold, a Harp, a Shamrock, a Shillelagh, and an Emerald.  The first player to return to Dublin with all five items is the winner.

On their journey player will visit the historical cities of Ireland , cross the River Shannon, find their Pot of Gold at the end of the Rainbow, ride in the Jaunting Car and encounter that mischievous elf of Irish folk-lore the Leprechaun.

But beware there are pitfalls of which the most ferocious is the Banshee.

To win you will need "THE LUCK O' THE IRISH"

Name: Rattlesnake City
Description:
You arrive at Rattlesnake Valley where you build a saloon with your last dollars.
With Rattlesnake City you will discover an exalted life, reconstructed cities, big ranches, old gold mines and a run-down rail way.
You will loot the banks, winning (perhaps) a game of poker and, most of all, you will not save up your bullets.
All means and ways to become the richest man in the west and the mayor of Rattlesnake City are welcome...

The game material consists of:
• The board that shows the valley, some ruins and the rail way
• 1 740 000 $ (in 120 bills)
• 90 bullets (in 54 cards)
• Cowboys, Mexicans, beautiful women, whiskey, tar and feathers, a set of poker cards
• Saloons, banks, mines, schools, hotels, general stores, sheriff, railway stations, churches, cemeteries and 72 pieces of rails track
• 36 wooden markers, a cloth bag, 2 rules overview and a full rules booklet

Name: Pigeon Poop
Description:
Mr. Boneyhead is late for work.  He just lives down the road from his office.  It'd be all so easy except for the pesky pigeon who has taken such a dislike to him.

As the pigeon you must drive Mr. Boneyhead off the street's end.  Use any of the tricks that your cards may allow you or... well... use what nature gave you in the end.

As Mr. Boneyhead you must make it to work period.  Use your umbrella and whatever the street offers up to you in order to get there.  And if you're of a nasty frame of mind... pluck that pigeon's feathers for him.  Take enough from his tail and he'll leave you alone while the other birds laugh at his fashion faux pas.

Pigeon Poop... you're in my sights now.

Name: Zombie Basketball
Description:
Zombie Basketball...

Enjoy the horror, the humour and the blood and guts of a game played by brave young men and shambling undead zombies.

Play against a friend or by yourself.

As a zombie team you can recruit new players from the opposing team... your bite is infectious and there is no cure.

As a human team... will your sharpshooter be good enough to keep the zeds off your back when you're going for the layup?

Try the game and claim some fame.

Zombie Basketball... are you man or are you meat?
Solitaire dice game in which you get to throw the dice exactly 30 times.  If you are efficient with your early tosses, you can use your saved throws to improve your score.

Name: Peek-a-boo Rummy
Description: A two-player Rummy variant where certain discards force cards in the draw deck to be exposed.
